review: Still waiting for this game like it's the Second Coming. At this point, I've convinced myself it's just an elaborate ARG and the real treasure was the friends we made while refreshing the Steam page for 6 years. If Silksong actually releases, I'm calling in sick to work, faking my own death, whatever it takes. Team Cherry could announce a release date of 2087 and we'd all still be like 'take your time kings, we trust the vision.' 10/10 for a game that may or may not exist in this timeline.
reviewComments: Bro I've been waiting since 2019. My beard has grown 3 feet. My wife left me. My kids don't recognize me. Still no Silksong.
At my funeral, instead of a eulogy, just play the Silksong trailer on loop. That's all I ever wanted to see anyway.
Team Cherry reading this review from their secret underground bunker, laughing maniacally while adding one more animation frame to a random enemy
The game is finished, they're just waiting for humanity to achieve world peace before releasing it
I'm convinced Silksong is actually a myth, like Bigfoot or functional AI companions in games

review: COPIUM REVIEW: Okay so I've played 0 hours of Silksong but based on the 2019 trailer and 47 frame-by-frame analyses I've watched, this is clearly going to be the greatest Metroidvania ever made. Hornet moves faster than the Knight, which means speedruns will be INSANE. The new areas look gorgeous, the music SLAPS, and I'm already planning my boss rush no-hit runs. Will I actually be good enough to do them? No. Will the game actually come out? Also no. But a man can dream. Rating: SHAW/10
reviewComments: My guy wrote a review for a game that doesn't exist. Respect the hustle.
Bro you forgot to mention the silk mechanics! Oh wait, we don't actually know how they work yet lmao
'SHAW/10' is sending me 💀
This is just fanfiction at this point but I'm here for it
When Silksong drops, this review is either gonna age like fine wine or spoiled milk. No in-between.

review: My grandkids will probably play this before I do. I've set aside $60 in my will specifically for purchasing Silksong on whatever holographic brain-chip store exists in 2075. Every Nintendo Direct, every Indie World showcase, every random Tuesday - I'm there, clown makeup on, ready to be disappointed again. The community has collectively lost our minds. We're finding hidden messages in Team Cherry's tax returns. We're analyzing the pixel density of decade-old screenshots. Someone started a cult. I joined it. No regrets.
reviewComments: THE CULT WELCOMES YOU BROTHER. We meet on Thursdays to pray to Mossbag for news.
Not the tax returns 😭😭😭 y'all are actually unhinged
I respect the dedication but maybe touch some grass? Actually no, grass might have hidden Silksong clues.
This man really said 2075 and honestly? That's optimistic. I'm thinking 2145 minimum.

review: Update: Still doesn't exist. But let me tell you about the LORE implications from that one screenshot Team Cherry posted in 2021. Hornet is clearly in a kingdom above Hallownest, which means the VOID lore might connect to... okay I'm not gonna lie, I've written a 40-page Google Doc about this. My family thinks I've lost it. They're right. But when Silksong finally drops and my theories are proven correct, who's gonna be laughing then? Me. Alone. In my room. Crying tears of joy. This game owns my soul and it's not even OUT.
reviewComments: Can... can I read that 40-page doc? For research purposes obviously.
Your family is correct, you have lost it, but so have we all. We're in this together king.
Hollow Knight fans writing more lore than actual game developers at this point
The dedication is admirable but also slightly concerning. Seek help. But also don't. But also do.
When you inevitably get everything wrong in your theories, just claim you were 'being artistic with the interpretation'

review: I've dreamed about playing this game so many times that I genuinely can't remember if I've actually played it or not. In my dreams, it's perfect. Hornet's movement is buttery smooth, the bosses are challenging but fair, and the soundtrack makes me cry. Then I wake up, check Twitter, see 'no news yet :)' from Team Cherry's last post from 2022, and go back to bed. I'm stuck in a timeloop. Send help. Or send Silksong. Preferably Silksong. Actually definitely Silksong.
reviewComments: This is the most relatable thing I've ever read. We're all trapped in the Silksong waiting room together.
Your dreams are just you playing Hollow Knight 1 but with extra steps lmao
I had a dream Team Cherry personally came to my house and told me the game was cancelled. Woke up in a cold sweat.
Bro turned Silksong anticipation into an existential crisis. We've gone too deep.

review: Finally, a COD game where I can get yelled at by a historically accurate drill sergeant while getting quickscoped by xXSniperElite420Xx. The campaign is actually good (yes, really), the multiplayer brings back boots on the ground gameplay, and the War mode is chaotic perfection. But let's be honest, I bought this to unlock camos and pretend I'm saving Private Ryan while some 12-year-old calls me trash in voice chat. The loot boxes are whatever. The real treasure is calling in a artillery strike and wiping a whole team. 8/10, would storm beaches again.
reviewComments: The campaign made me actually feel things?? In a COD game?? What timeline is this??
War mode is lowkey the best thing COD has done in years. The tug-of-war gameplay is *chef's kiss*
Remember when everyone complained about 'boots on ground' and then we got jetpacks and everyone wanted this back? Good times.
xXSniperElite420Xx is definitely someone's username and they definitely destroyed me last night
The headquarters social space was actually kinda cool until it became a cesspool of people opening loot boxes

review: This game taught me that I am, in fact, terrible at video games. I thought I was decent at COD until I got into a lobby with people who treat this game like it's their full-time job. The hit detection is... questionable at times. The spawns are sometimes wack. But when you get that quad feed with the STG-44? Pure dopamine. The zombies mode is also surprisingly solid. Nazi zombies are back baby, and they're angrier than ever. Also shoutout to whoever designed the MP40 - that gun SLAPS.
reviewComments: The STG-44 is absolutely cracked in this game, it's my go-to every single match
Spawns in this game are basically a coin flip between 'safe' and 'instantly dead'
Nazi zombies never gets old. Something therapeutic about mowing down undead fascists.
My KD is 0.7 but my spirit is unbreakable. That's what counts right?
The MP40 sound design alone deserves an award. That *tack tack tack* is beautiful

review: Honestly solid COD entry. The removal of the advanced movement is both a blessing and a curse - blessing because I don't have to worry about some tryhard flying at me from orbit, curse because now I actually have to aim and can't blame my deaths on 'momentum'. The division system is interesting but kinda restrictive. Campaign is genuinely moving at times, which is weird to say about a COD game. Multiplayer is sweaty as expected. If you miss the 'golden era' of COD, this is a decent throwback. 7.5/10
reviewComments: The division system was interesting in theory but in practice everyone just ran Infantry or Airborne lol
This game made me realize that maybe I didn't actually hate advanced movement, I just hated being bad at it
The campaign is underrated. That ending sequence hit different.
Sweaty is an understatement. Some of these lobbies are like watching eSports tryouts

review: Back to basics COD, which is exactly what the franchise needed after the jet-pack era. No more flying around like Iron Man on crack. Just pure, unadulterated shooting. The maps are mostly solid, though some are camp-fests. The weapons feel punchy and satisfying. The progression system keeps you grinding (for better or worse). And yes, I absolutely spent way too much time in the headquarters 1v1 pit settling disputes like we're in middle school. No shame. This game is what happens when COD remembers its roots.
reviewComments: The 1v1 pit was genuinely such a good addition. Settled so many arguments there lmao
Some of these maps are camping simulator 2017 but that's every COD tbh
The grind for chrome camo almost broke me as a person but I got it and now I'm hollow inside
I miss jetpacks sometimes but then I play this and remember how nice it is to have my feet on the ground
'Pure, unadulterated shooting' perfectly describes this game. It's COD in its essence.

review: Look, I'm just here for the zombies. The multiplayer is fine, the campaign is fine, but Nazi Zombies is where it's at. The storyline is actually interesting, the Easter eggs are challenging without being impossible, and there's something deeply satisfying about watching wave after wave of zombies get absolutely annihilated. I've spent more hours on The Final Reich than I care to admit. My friends think I'm weird. They're probably right. But when we finally beat that Easter egg at 3 AM, screaming into our mics? Worth it.
reviewComments: Nazi Zombies in this game is criminally underrated. People slept on it hard.
The Final Reich is such a good starting map. Good balance of difficulty and fun.
I've watched so many YouTube tutorials on these Easter eggs that I could probably recite them in my sleep
There's dozen of us! Dozens! Who prefer this zombies mode to the Treyarch versions
3 AM Easter egg completions hit different. That's when the real gaming happens.

gameName: The Last of Us Part II
review: This game took my emotions, put them in a blender, and hit puree for 25 hours straight. The gameplay is fantastic - stealth, combat, exploration all feel weighty and brutal. The graphics are stunning. But the story? Oh boy. This game will either make you ugly cry or furiously debate on Reddit for months. Maybe both. Playing as Abby was controversial but honestly, her sections were some of the most intense moments. The ending left me staring at my screen for 20 minutes in silence. 9/10 would get emotionally devastated again.
reviewComments: I'm still not over THAT scene at the beginning. It's been years and I'm still not over it.
The Abby sections were actually fire once I got over being salty about playing as her. The Rat King boss fight??? INSANE
This game proves you can make a sequel that divides the fanbase but is still objectively brilliant from a technical standpoint
I finished this game and immediately needed therapy. 10/10 experience, would not recommend to anyone with a fragile emotional state
Reddit arguments about this game could power a small country with all the energy people waste debating it

gameName: The Last of Us Part II
review: Naughty Dog said 'let's make the most beautiful game ever' and then 'let's make it emotionally traumatizing'. Mission accomplished. Every frame is screenshot-worthy. The facial animations are scary good - I could see Ellie's rage and pain in her eyes. The accessibility options are incredible too. But man, this game is HEAVY. It's not a fun time, it's an experience. Like watching Schindler's List but with more fungal zombies. Gameplay is smooth, satisfying, brutal. The guitar sections hit different. 9.5/10, destroyed my mental health.
reviewComments: The accessibility options in this game set a new standard for the industry. Massive respect to Naughty Dog for that.
Every time there was a guitar section I got emotional. Ellie playing Take On Me broke me.
The facial animations are so good it's actually uncanny. Like I felt uncomfortable looking at some characters because they felt TOO real
Comparing it to Schindler's List is accurate. Both are masterpieces that I never want to experience again.

gameName: The Last of Us Part II
review: This game is a masterclass in 'how to make everyone mad at you while still making an incredible game'. The level design is phenomenal. Seattle feels alive (or well, dead, but you know what I mean). The attention to detail is insane - you can see footprints in the snow, Ellie's breath in the cold, every little thing. Combat is visceral and uncomfortable, which is the point. The story asks 'what does revenge cost' and the answer is EVERYTHING including my emotional stability. Whether you love or hate the story, you can't deny the craftsmanship. 8.5/10
reviewComments: The footprints in the snow detail is something I noticed and it made me appreciate how much work went into this game
Seattle is basically a character itself. The environments are breathtaking and depressing at the same time.
I love how the game makes you feel BAD for killing people. Most games reward violence, this one punishes you emotionally.
The 'revenge costs everything' theme is heavy-handed but effective. I felt like garbage by the end.
Craftsmanship is the perfect word. Even if you hate the story, you have to respect the technical achievement

gameName: The Last of Us Part II
review: Okay so I went into this game expecting to hate Abby forever. And then Naughty Dog hit me with her storyline and suddenly I'm like 'wait... I get it now'. That's storytelling, baby. The way they make you understand both perspectives is genius even if it's uncomfortable. Gameplay-wise, it's the perfect evolution of Part I. More refined, more options, more brutal. The infected are terrifying. The Stalkers gave me PTSD. And that Rat King? Nightmare fuel. This game respects your intelligence while destroying your soul. 9/10
reviewComments: The Rat King is genuinely one of the scariest video game bosses I've ever fought. Absolutely horrifying.
I was Team Hate Abby for like 10 hours and then her story clicked and I was like... oh no, I'm invested now
Stalkers are proof that Naughty Dog has a personal vendetta against people who enjoy feeling safe
The way this game forces empathy is uncomfortable but brilliant. Most games let you choose, this one forces you to understand.
Anyone who says they didn't jump at least once during the Stalker sections is a liar

gameName: The Last of Us Part II
review: I have complex feelings about this game, which I think is the point. It's not designed to make you feel good - it's designed to make you FEEL, period. The violence has weight and consequence. The characters are flawed and human. Ellie's journey is painful to watch. The game doesn't give you easy answers or satisfying conclusions, and that's what makes it memorable. Gameplay is tight, graphics are unreal, sound design is *chef's kiss*. It's not perfect, but it's unforgettable. 8.5/10, would emotionally suffer again.
reviewComments: The sound design in this game is criminally underrated. The way the audio cues work in stealth sections is perfection.
I appreciate that the game treats the player like an adult who can handle moral complexity
The violence feeling heavy is so important. Most games make it feel consequence-free and this game absolutely does not.
Not giving easy answers is brave. Most games would cave and give you the 'hero wins' ending.
Unforgettable is the perfect word. For better or worse, this game sticks with you.

review: This game is what happens when Rockstar decides to make the most detailed, immersive, beautiful game possible and also make you watch 30-minute horse rides as part of the experience. The story is a masterpiece - Arthur Morgan is one of the greatest protagonists in gaming. The world feels ALIVE. NPCs remember you. Your horse will throw you if you're mean to it. You can watch your beard grow in real-time (yes, really). But holy moly the pacing is SLOW. Chapter 5 almost broke me. Still, when those sunset rides hit with the soundtrack? *chef's kiss* 9.5/10 boahs
reviewComments: Arthur Morgan's character arc made me cry like a baby. That's not hyperbole. Literal tears.
The horse bonding system is more complex than most RPG companion systems and I'm here for it
Chapter 5 is Rockstar's way of testing if you're truly committed. It's a slog but the payoff is worth it.
I spent 20 minutes just watching my beard grow once. This game has turned me into a digital hermit.
Those sunset rides with the music swelling? That's ART. That's CINEMA. That's peak gaming.

review: I've spent 200 hours on this game and I'm still discovering new things. Random encounters, stranger missions, hidden details everywhere. Rockstar built an entire functioning ecosystem. You can watch predators hunt prey. You can greet or antagonize every NPC with unique dialogue. The attention to detail is ABSURD. Arthur's journal entries change based on your honor level. Your guns get dirty and need cleaning. The camp feels like home. The story will break your heart. The ending? I'm not crying, YOU'RE crying. 10/10 partner
reviewComments: 200 hours is rookie numbers. I'm at 500+ and still finding new stuff. This game is infinite.
The fact that Arthur's journal changes based on your choices shows the insane level of detail Rockstar put in
Camp interactions are underrated. Just hanging out with the gang, listening to their stories... it's perfect.
The ending destroyed me. I had to take a week off from gaming to emotionally recover.
The dirty gun mechanic seems tedious until you realize it's just another layer of immersion. Then it's beautiful.

review: This game is simultaneously the best and most frustrating game I've ever played. Best because it's a technical marvel with incredible storytelling. Frustrating because the controls are CLUNKY. I've accidentally pulled my gun on so many people when trying to say hello. The looting animation takes forever. But once you accept the deliberate pace, it becomes meditative. You're not rushing to objective markers - you're living in the world. Hunting is therapeutic. Fishing by a lake at dawn? Perfection. The story of the gang's decline is Shakespeare-level tragedy. 9/10
reviewComments: I've started so many accidental shootouts by pressing the wrong button. The controls are my mortal enemy.
Once you embrace the slow pace, the game transforms from frustrating to zen. It's wild.
Hunting in this game is more engaging than entire gameplay loops in other games
The gang's story is genuinely Shakespearean. Dutch's descent into madness is brilliantly done.
I've spent hours just fishing and thinking about life. This game is therapy.

review: If you told me 10 years ago that I'd be emotionally invested in a video game horse, I'd call you crazy. But here we are. My horse died during a mission and I genuinely mourned. I named her Esmerelda and we rode thousands of miles together. RDR2 makes you care about everything - your horse, your gang, random NPCs you meet once. The game is a love letter to westerns and open-world design. Sure, it's slower than molasses sometimes, but that's part of its charm. When Arthur says 'thank you' to his horse, I FELT that. 10/10
reviewComments: I ugly cried when my horse died. Had that thing since Chapter 2. RIP Butterscotch, you were the real one.
The fact that Arthur thanks his horse is such a small detail but it shows his character perfectly
This game turned me into a person who roleplays as a cowboy. I greet everyone in town now.
I've become attached to digital horses in a way that concerns my therapist
The game's ability to make you care about seemingly minor things is its greatest achievement

review: Red Dead 2 is what peak video game design looks like - for better or worse. It's stunning, immersive, emotional, and occasionally tedious. The story missions are incredible but sometimes the game forces you to play it exactly how Rockstar wants with zero deviation. The epilogue is longer than some full games (and honestly? It's fantastic). The online mode is... well, we don't talk about that. But the single player? It's an experience. You don't just play RDR2, you LIVE it. Prepare for 60+ hours of cowboy life. 9.5/10, would get tuberculosis again
reviewComments: The epilogue is so good it could be its own game. Building the house? Peak gaming moment.
RDR Online had so much potential and Rockstar just... gave up on it. Tragic.
The mission design can be restrictive but the story they're telling is so good I forgive it
Getting tuberculosis as a plot point was such a bold choice and it WORKED
'Would get tuberculosis again' is the most RDR2 sentence ever written

review: What a journey this game has been. Launched as a beautiful disaster, now it's actually incredible post-updates. Night City is the most visually stunning game world I've ever seen. The neon, the grime, the verticality - it's Blade Runner on steroids. The story with Johnny Silverhand is great, Keanu Reeves is charmingly Keanu. Combat feels good, builds are diverse. But man, those first months were ROUGH. Now with the 2.0 update? It's the game we were promised. The redemption arc is real. 8.5/10, would glitch through walls again (but less now)
reviewComments: This game's redemption arc is like watching a phoenix rise from the ashes, except the phoenix is on fire and confused but doing its best
Night City at night is genuinely breathtaking. I've lost hours just walking around looking at stuff.
Keanu as Johnny Silverhand is perfect casting. He's just being himself but in the future.
I remember launch day. Dark times. We've come so far. Phantom Liberty made me believe again.
The fact that CDPR actually fixed this game instead of abandoning it deserves massive respect

review: Cyberpunk 2077 is proof that first impressions aren't everything. Launch? Catastrophic. Now? Genuinely fantastic. The RPG elements are deep, the side quests are better than most games' main quests, and Night City feels alive with detail. The different endings actually matter based on your choices. Netrunner builds are hilariously OP. Sandevistan builds make you feel like you're in The Matrix. The story tackles heavy themes - identity, mortality, capitalism. Plus you can pet cats. What more do you want? 9/10
reviewComments: Netrunner builds are so broken you can clear entire buildings without being seen. It's glorious.
The side quest with the AI taxi had me more emotional than some games' entire campaigns
Being able to pet cats is an instant +1 to any game. This is science.
The endings are all depressing in different ways and I love it. No easy outs.
Going from launch disaster to actually good game is the ultimate underdog story

review: I played this at launch on PS4 and thought I was being pranked. Played it again after 2.0 on PC and holy optimization, Batman, it's like a different game. The narrative is tight - every mission with Johnny feels meaningful. The characters are memorable (Panam best girl, fight me). The city is a character itself. My only gripe is that some of the gameplay systems still feel half-baked, but the core experience is solid. If you bounced off at launch, give it another shot. CDPR pulled off a No Man's Sky tier comeback. 8/10
reviewComments: PS4 launch was legit traumatic. I thought my console was dying. Turns out the game was dying.
Panam is best girl and this is objective fact, not opinion. I will die on this hill.
The No Man's Sky comparison is apt. Both games became what they were meant to be, just... later.
Johnny's missions are all bangers. The flashback sequences are so well done.
The comeback is real but I'll never forget the disaster launch. Trust issues remain.

review: Night City is my favorite virtual place. I've spent countless hours just walking the streets, eating ramen at food stalls, watching the rain on neon signs. The vibes are immaculate. Yes, the game had a rough start. Yes, some promised features never came. But what we have now is special. The writing is sharp, the voice acting is top-tier, and the Phantom Liberty DLC is genuinely excellent. The relic mechanic adds urgency to the story. This is the cyberpunk game I dreamed about since reading Neuromancer. 9/10, wake the f*** up samurai
reviewComments: The food stall scenes hit different. Something about the atmosphere just works perfectly.
Phantom Liberty added so much. Idris Elba was a perfect addition to the cast.
The relic mechanic creating a ticking clock is brilliant game design. Forces you to care about the urgency.
This game nails the cyberpunk FEELING. Not just the aesthetic, but the themes too.
'Wake the f*** up samurai' lives rent-free in my head and will never leave

review: Cyberpunk 2077 is the game that taught me that patience is a virtue and pre-ordering is a sin. But jokes aside, the current state of this game is impressive. The combat has weight, the music is phenomenal (that title screen theme though), and Night City is dense with content. The main story is maybe 20-30 hours but the side content is where it shines. Every gig feels handcrafted. The world building is S-tier. Photo mode is addictive. My only complaint: why can't I customize my character more mid-game? 8.5/10 chooms
reviewComments: The soundtrack is a masterpiece. Samurai's tracks go so hard. Johnny would be proud.
Photo mode in this game is dangerous. I've spent hours taking screenshots instead of playing.
The world building is better than some actual sci-fi novels. The lore is DEEP.
Not being able to change appearance mid-game is such a weird oversight. Let me change my hair at least!
Calling everyone 'choom' has entered my actual vocabulary. This game has changed me.

review: Finally, we're going back to the roots - 1900s Sicily. This is the Mafia origin story we didn't know we needed. The atmosphere is incredible - cobblestone streets, old-world architecture, that sepia-toned aesthetic. Combat feels grounded and brutal, as it should. The story seems focused on how organized crime actually started, which is fascinating. Early previews suggest this is more grounded than Mafia III's action-heavy approach. If they nail the storytelling like Mafia II, this could be special. Can't wait to build my criminal empire with period-authentic violence. 9/10 (potential)
reviewComments: Setting it in 1900s Sicily is genius. We're finally getting the TRUE origin story.
The period aesthetic looks beautiful. Hangar 13 is really committing to the historical setting.
I hope they keep it grounded like Mafia II. That game was a masterpiece of atmosphere.
Building a criminal empire from literally the beginning? Take my money.
If this is anything like Mafia II but in Sicily, I'm gonna lose my mind in the best way

review: Mafia going back to Sicily is like Star Wars going back to Tatooine - it just WORKS. The footage we've seen looks incredibly atmospheric. The violence looks weighty and consequential, not arcadey. I'm hoping for a slow-burn narrative about family, honor, betrayal - all that good Godfather stuff. The Mafia series has always been at its best when it focuses on character-driven stories in specific time periods. This setting is perfect for that. Really hoping they don't oversaturate it with modern open-world bloat. Keep it tight, keep it focused. 8.5/10 (based on vibes)
reviewComments: The Godfather comparison is apt. This really could be gaming's answer to that if done right.
Praying they don't fill this with unnecessary collectibles and busy work. Story first.
The early 1900s setting is so underutilized in games. This could be something special.
Character-driven Mafia stories are what the series does best. Hope they lean into that.

review: Look, I'm cautiously optimistic. Mafia III was... divisive. But this looks like a return to form. Sicily in the 1900s is ripe for storytelling. The trailer gave me chills - that old-world atmosphere, the tension, the promise of a slow-burn crime epic. I'm hoping for deep character relationships, moral complexity, and that signature Mafia attention to period detail. If they can combine Mafia II's narrative focus with better gameplay variety, we're golden. Not reviewing the full game yet but my expectations are sky-high. Don't let me down, Hangar 13.
reviewComments: Mafia III had issues but the story was still great. If they fix the gameplay loop, this will be incredible.
The trailer was all atmosphere and no gameplay, which either means it's amazing or they're hiding something.
Moral complexity in crime games is so important. Make me question my choices!
The period detail in previous Mafia games was always on point. Expecting the same here.
My expectations are dangerously high. Prepare for disappointment or ecstasy, no in-between.

review: Mafia is going back to its roots, literally. Sicily, 1900s, origins of organized crime. Everything about this concept screams potential. The series has always excelled at creating time period authenticity - the music, the fashion, the cars, the language. This is going to be all of that but with even more historical weight. I'm imagining vendetta-driven storylines, family honor, rising through the ranks in brutal fashion. If the gameplay supports the narrative ambition, this could be GOTY material. Manifesting a masterpiece. 9.5/10 (hopium rating)
reviewComments: The historical setting gives them so much to work with. Don't waste this opportunity!
Vendetta-driven storylines in early 1900s Sicily? That's literally the perfect setup.
I've never been more excited for a Mafia game. The potential is INSANE.
GOTY material IF they execute. That's a big if, but I believe.

review: This is either going to be a masterpiece or a beautiful disaster, and honestly? I'm here for either outcome. The setting is perfect. Sicily in 1900 is when the Mafia as we know it was really taking shape. The opportunity for authentic storytelling is incredible. My hope is that they focus on a tight, personal story rather than trying to make a huge open world. Give me Mafia II's focus with modern gameplay refinements. That's all I want. The aesthetic is already perfect based on what we've seen. Now nail the execution. Godspeed, Hangar 13. 8/10 (preemptive)
reviewComments: Beautiful disaster would still be entertaining so honestly it's a win-win
Tight personal stories > bloated open worlds. This is the way.
Mafia II is still the gold standard for this series. Match that energy.
The aesthetic alone has me sold. Now just don't mess up the story and gameplay.
Godspeed indeed. We're all rooting for this game to be incredible.

review: Tarkov but make it accessible? Sign me up. Arena Breakout hits that extraction shooter itch without making me feel like I need a PhD in ballistics. The gunplay is satisfying, the tension is real, and the learning curve is steep but not vertical like some other games (*cough* Tarkov *cough*). The 'Infinite' version brings it to PC with solid optimization. Maps are well designed, loot economy feels balanced. It's not revolutionary but it's SOLID. If you want Tarkov-lite without the Russian jank, this is your game. 8/10 rats
reviewComments: As a Tarkov player, this is like methadone. It scratches the itch without the full addiction.
The optimization is surprisingly good. No stutters, decent frames, actual functioning servers.
Tarkov-lite is exactly what this is and that's not an insult. It's what we needed.
The loot economy being balanced is a feature, not a bug. Tarkov flea market has me in shambles.
Rats unite! The extraction shooter genre is thriving and I'm here for all of it.

review: This game is proof that you don't need to reinvent the wheel, just make it rounder. It takes the extraction shooter formula and streamlines it. Still hardcore, still punishing, but not unnecessarily obtuse. The progression feels good, the weapon customization is deep, and the raid structure keeps you coming back. My heart rate during extract is still through the roof. The mobile version was surprisingly good, the PC version is even better. If you've been intimidated by Tarkov, start here. 8.5/10
reviewComments: My Apple Watch thinks I'm exercising when I'm extracting with good loot. The stress is real.
The progression system feels rewarding without being impossible like some other games.
Started here before Tarkov and honestly? Glad I did. Good training wheels.
Weapon customization is so deep I've spent hours in menus just building guns
The transition from mobile to PC is seamless. They did it right.

review: Arena Breakout is the extraction shooter for people who have jobs and responsibilities. You can get in, do a raid, extract, and actually feel accomplished in 20-30 minutes. Compare that to Tarkov where one raid can be an hour-long commitment to suffering. The gunplay is punchy, the armor system makes sense, and the maps are sized appropriately. It's not trying to be a mil-sim - it's trying to be FUN, and it succeeds. Also it doesn't eat my GPU alive like some games. 8/10
reviewComments: Having a job and playing extraction shooters is genuinely difficult. This game respects my time.
20-30 minute raids are perfect. I can actually play more than once per evening.
The armor system making sense is such a low bar but SO many games fail at it
My GPU thanks me for playing this instead of other unoptimized messes
FUN is such an underrated goal in hardcore games. Not everything needs to be Dark Souls.

review: As someone who got filtered hard by Tarkov, Arena Breakout is a blessing. It has the tension, the risk-reward, the dopamine hit of extracting with good loot, but without making me feel like I need a master's degree to understand healing animations. The tutorial actually teaches you things. The UI is comprehensible. The learning curve exists but it's not a learning cliff. Still plenty hardcore - I've lost millions to better players. But I feel like I'm learning and improving rather than just getting destroyed. 8/10
reviewComments: Tarkov filtered me so hard I thought extraction shooters weren't for me. This game proved me wrong.
A tutorial that actually teaches? Revolutionary. Other games should take notes.
UI/UX in hardcore games is often terrible. This game actually respects player experience.
Lost millions but learned from my mistakes. That's good game design.
Learning cliff vs learning curve is the perfect way to describe the difference

review: This game is comfort food in extraction shooter form. It's familiar if you've played the genre, polished enough to feel good, and just accessible enough to not be gatekeepy. The weapon modding is satisfying, the sound design is solid, and the economy isn't completely borked (looking at you, every other extraction shooter). My only gripe is that it sometimes feels a bit too safe - like it's not willing to take risks. But honestly? In a genre full of janky ambitious disasters, 'safe and polished' is refreshing. 7.5/10
reviewComments: Comfort food games are underrated. Sometimes you just want something familiar but good.
The economy not being borked is such a huge W. I can actually make money as a casual player.
Safe and polished > ambitious disaster. Hot take but I stand by it.
Sound design is lowkey great. Directional audio actually works for once.
The genre IS full of janky disasters so this being stable is actually impressive

review: After 15 years, we're back in The Zone baby! S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2 is everything I wanted - brutal, atmospheric, beautiful, and janky in that special Eastern European way. The graphics are stunning, The Zone feels alive and hostile, the AI is surprisingly smart (and terrifying). The anomalies will kill you. The mutants will kill you. Other stalkers will kill you. Your own greed will kill you. It's perfect. Yes there are bugs, but that's part of the charm. If you want polish, play something else. If you want ATMOSPHERE, get in here stalker. 9/10 cheeki breeki
reviewComments: The Zone atmosphere is unmatched. Walking through the foggy swamps at night is pure horror.
The bugs are a feature, not a bug. This is authentic S.T.A.L.K.E.R. experience.
AI stalkers actually flanking me and using tactics? In MY game? It's more likely than you think.
Died to an anomaly I couldn't see because of weather effects. 10/10 would get annihilated again.
CHEEKI BREEKI IV DAMKE - if you know, you know. Welcome home stalkers.

review: This game doesn't hold your hand - it pushes you into an anomaly and laughs. The survival mechanics are hardcore. Radiation is everywhere. Food is scarce. Ammo is precious. Every expedition into The Zone is a calculated risk. The story is classic S.T.A.L.K.E.R. - weird, cryptic, fascinating. The factions all feel distinct with believable motivations. Graphics on max settings are jaw-dropping. It's the most beautiful post-apocalyptic hellscape I've ever seen. Some technical issues exist but GSC Game World is actively fixing them. 8.5/10
reviewComments: The game pushing you into anomalies is literally what happens. I've been killed by the tutorial.
Survival mechanics are so hardcore I'm stressed just thinking about my next food source
Faction system is deep. I've accidentally made enemies with everyone. Oops.
Most beautiful hellscape is accurate. Screenshots look like concept art.
GSC actively fixing bugs gives me hope. They care about this franchise.

review: Get out of here stalker, and by that I mean get IN here because this game rules. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2 is the immersive sim we deserved. Every approach works if you're clever. Stealth? Viable. Guns blazing? Possible but costly. Avoiding combat entirely? Smart. The open-world design is genius - main quest exists but you can get sidetracked for hours doing faction missions or just exploring. Found a crashed helicopter with rare loot but had to fight a Bloodsucker in a dark tunnel. Peak gaming. 9/10
reviewComments: The 'get out of here stalker' meme will never die and I'm okay with that
Immersive sim design in an open world? More games need to do this.
Bloodsucker fights in dark areas are legit scary. I've Alt+F4'd more than once.
Getting sidetracked is the actual gameplay. The main quest is just a suggestion.
Found rare loot, immediately died to emission. The Zone giveth and taketh away.

review: This game is a love letter to hardcore single-player FPS fans. No hand-holding, no quest markers every 5 feet, no easy mode. You have a map, a compass, and your wits. Figure it out. The sound design is INCREDIBLE - every creak, every distant gunshot, every anomaly hum adds to the tension. The weather system affects gameplay meaningfully. Emissions force you to find shelter. The A-Life system makes The Zone feel unpredictable. It's not perfect but it's SPECIAL. If you loved the originals, you'll love this. 9/10
reviewComments: No quest markers is so refreshing. Makes me actually pay attention to the world.
Sound design is genuinely Oscar-worthy. Every sound tells a story and/or terrifies you.
The weather affecting gameplay isn't just aesthetic. Storms legitimately change how you play.
A-Life 2.0 makes the world feel alive. NPCs are doing their own thing independent of me.
If you bounced off because it's hard, that's valid. But you're missing out.

review: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2 is the game I've been waiting 15 years for and it was worth the wait. The Zone is bigger, more detailed, more dangerous than ever. The graphics are nuts - DLSS and ray-tracing make it look unreal. But the soul of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is intact: brutal difficulty, compelling mysteries, faction warfare, and that special Slavic jank we all know and love. My only complaint is performance can be rough even on good hardware. But GSC is patching fast. This is survival FPS at its finest. 9/10, slava ukraini.
reviewComments: Been waiting since 2010. The weight of expectation was huge. They delivered.
Ray-tracing in The Zone is both beautiful and terrifying. Shadows move and I panic.
Performance is the only real issue. Everything else is either good or fixable.
That Slavic jank is part of the experience. It wouldn't be S.T.A.L.K.E.R. without it.
The devs made this game during a war. The dedication is incredible. Support them.

review: The greatest redemption arc in gaming history. Launched as a lie, now it's everything promised and MORE. The foundation is exploration across infinite procedurally generated planets. Then they added base building. Then vehicles. Then multiplayer. Then settlements. Then frigates. Then expeditions. Hello Games just kept GOING. Every planet feels unique, the space combat is fun, the story is surprisingly philosophical. You can play for thousands of hours and still find new stuff. 9/10, would travel 18 quintillion planets again.
reviewComments: This game's comeback story should be taught in business schools. Unreal turnaround.
I've played 500 hours and barely scratched the surface. The content is ENDLESS.
The fact that Hello Games kept updating for FREE is insane. No DLC, just updates.
The story gets surprisingly deep with existential themes. Not what I expected from space game.
Found a planet with giant floating worms. This game is a fever dream and I love it.

review: From meme to dream. No Man's Sky is the little engine that could. At launch: disastrous. Now: incredible. The gameplay loop is addictive - explore, gather, craft, build, repeat. The universes are genuinely endless. You can be a trader, a fighter, an explorer, a base builder, whatever. The multiplayer expeditions are fun community events. The VR mode is mindblowing. And Hello Games STILL releases massive free updates. If you wrote this game off at launch, give it another shot. It's not the same game. 9/10
reviewComments: The VR mode is genuinely one of the best VR experiences period. Flying through space in VR is WILD.
Expeditions are great for bringing people back. Limited time events with unique rewards.
I wrote this off in 2016. Came back in 2024. It's a completely different game. Insane.
The fact they're still updating is crazy. Most devs would've abandoned ship.
From meme to dream is perfect. This is the ultimate underdog story.

review: No Man's Sky is now what we all imagined it would be in 2016, except better. The exploration is serene and beautiful. Finding that perfect paradise planet and building a base there is incredibly satisfying. The universe feels massive but not empty. Other players' bases pop up on planets, making you feel less alone. The story about the Atlas and the nature of reality is trippy. My only gripe: inventory management is still tedious. But that's a small complaint for a game this huge. 8.5/10
reviewComments: Found my perfect planet after 200 hours. It has blue grass and flying eels. It's home now.
Seeing other players' bases makes the universe feel lived in. It's weirdly comforting.
The Atlas story blew my mind. The ending made me question reality. In a space game!
Inventory management is the final boss of this game. So much sorting and transferring.
This game is perfect for putting on chill music and just vibing through space

review: This game is meditation in video game form. Sometimes I just fly around, scan creatures, take screenshots. It's therapeutic. The grind can be real if you're rushing, but if you take your time and enjoy the journey, it's wonderful. Every update adds something meaningful. The community is wholesome. Hello Games proved that you can recover from the worst launch imaginable through sheer determination and free content. It's not perfect - still some repetition - but it's special. 8.5/10
reviewComments: This game is my zen space. Bad day? Fly around scanning space cows. Instant calm.
The grind is only bad if you're racing. Take your time, smell the alien roses.
The NMS community is genuinely one of the nicest gaming communities. Very welcoming.
Hello Games' redemption inspired other devs. The ripple effect is real.
Repetition exists but when the core loop is this relaxing, I don't mind

review: Sean Murray went from most hated man in gaming to beloved indie dev through pure work ethic. No Man's Sky is a monument to 'never give up'. The game now has everything: exploration, combat, building, trading, multiplayer, story, settlements, freighters, mech suits, living ships, THE LIST GOES ON. It's the space sim I always wanted. Finding weird planets with bizarre flora and fauna never gets old. If you haven't tried it since launch, you owe it to yourself. It's incredible. 9/10
reviewComments: Sean Murray's redemption arc > any fictional character's arc. The man rebuilt his reputation through work.
Living ships are so weird and I love them. Biological spaceships? Sign me up.
The feature list is so long I forget half of what's even in the game
Finding planets with weird stuff is the best. Found one with bouncing mushrooms as tall as mountains.
This is THE comeback story for video games. Period.

review: This game is pure, unfiltered chaos and I'm here for it. Physics-based combat with intentionally wonky animations creates comedy gold. Watching a bunch of peasants take down a mammoth through sheer numerical advantage never gets old. The campaign is fun, but the real joy is in the sandbox mode - creating absurd battles and watching them unfold. Will 100 chickens beat 10 knights? Let's find out! The ragdolls are hilarious, the unit variety is great, and the modding community is insane. 8/10, would flail wildly again.
reviewComments: 100 chickens vs 10 knights is a legitimate experiment I've run. Chickens won. Don't ask how.
The ragdoll physics are responsible for 90% of my enjoyment. Bodies flying everywhere.
Campaign is fine but I've spent 50+ hours in sandbox just making dumb battles
Modding community has added everything from Star Wars units to anime characters. It's glorious chaos.
This game is what happens when physics engines are given too much freedom and I love it

review: TABS is a masterclass in controlled chaos. The premise is simple: set up two armies and watch them fight. The execution is hilarious. Units stumble around, weapons flail wildly, and physics does whatever it wants. The tactics are surprisingly deep though - positioning matters, unit composition matters, terrain matters. You can spend hours perfecting strategies or just throw 1000 units at each other and see what happens. Both are valid. The secret units are fun to discover. This is physics sandbox perfection. 8.5/10
reviewComments: I spent 3 hours perfecting a strategy to beat one level. Then accidentally beat it with random units. Pain.
Physics doing whatever it wants is the core experience. A unit tripped and killed an enemy commander once.
Secret units are so fun to find. The Chicken Man God is OP and terrifying.
1000 unit battles tank my framerate but the carnage is worth it
Surprisingly deep tactics in what looks like a meme game. That's good design.

review: If you ever wondered 'can 50 club men beat a tank', this is your game. TABS answers questions nobody asked but everybody wanted to know. The physics-based combat creates emergent moments of brilliance and comedy. A peasant once accidentally killed himself with his own weapon, eliminating the enemy behind him. That's the TABS experience. The unit creator is fun for making custom armies. The workshop has thousands of custom battles. Great value for a silly physics game. 7.5/10
reviewComments: The answer is yes, 50 club men CAN beat a tank if they get lucky with the physics
Emergent moments are the best. Watched a unit get launched across the map and score a kill on landing.
The unit creator is wild. People have made everything. No limits. Pure creativity.
Workshop content means this game never ends. Always new battles to try.
Silly physics games are underrated. Not everything needs to be serious.

review: TABS is what I show people when they ask what I like about video games. The immediate visual comedy of wobbly warriors hitting each other with foam weapons hooks everyone. Then they realize there's actual strategy involved and they're hooked. It's accessible to anyone but has depth for people who want it. The campaign progressively introduces new units and challenges. The sandbox is infinite entertainment. For like 15 bucks, you get hundreds of hours of potential fun. That's incredible value. 8/10
reviewComments: Showed this to my non-gamer friend. They played for 4 hours straight. Mission accomplished.
Foam weapons that somehow deal damage is peak comedy. The jiggle physics are *chef's kiss*
Accessibility is so important. Anyone can play this and have fun immediately.
Campaign is genuinely well designed. Good difficulty curve, creative challenges.
$15 for this much content is a steal. Indie pricing done right.

review: This game is a stress reliever. Bad day? Watch knights get annihilated by chicken farmers. Feeling good? Create the most balanced battle possible and watch it unfold. TABS works in any mood. The simplicity is its strength - there's no complicated mechanics to learn, just place units and go. The physics handle the rest. The developer keeps adding content too. Recent updates added new factions and units. It's the gift that keeps giving. Perfect game to play while listening to podcasts or music. 8/10
reviewComments: Stress reliever is accurate. This game is therapeutic in the weirdest way.
Perfectly balanced battles are satisfying to watch. Like watching art in motion. Violent art.
Playing this while listening to podcasts is my go-to. Brain off, just vibes and chaos.
Devs still updating years later? That's dedication. Respect.
Knights vs chicken farmers is a rivalry for the ages

review: Square Enix said 'let's take a 20-hour game and make it 40 hours by only doing Midgar' and somehow it WORKS. The combat is incredible - perfect blend of action and strategy. Character development is deep, the voice acting is top-tier, and they managed to flesh out parts of the story that were glossed over in the original. The Sector 7 pillar sequence hit harder than expected. Graphics are stunning. My only gripes: some padding is obvious and it's only part 1 of a trilogy. But what's here is fantastic. 9/10, can't wait for part 3 in 2035
reviewComments: The combat system is perfection. Tactical mode is genius. Makes every fight engaging.
Sector 7 pillar had me crying. They really made you CARE about these characters.
The padding is real - some chapters drag. But the highs are so high I forgive it.
Waiting for part 3 is going to kill me. I'll be 50 years old by the time we see the finale.
They expanded Midgar so well. Areas I barely remembered from 1997 are now fleshed out and beautiful

review: This isn't just a remake, it's a reimagining. The story has been expanded, characters have more depth, and the combat is phenomenal. Tifa's combat is so smooth and satisfying. Barrett's character arc is way better than the original. Aerith is perfect. Cloud is angsty as always. The boss fights are spectacular set pieces. The music arrangements are gorgeous - some of the best video game music period. It's not perfect - the linearity can feel restrictive - but it's a love letter to fans. 9/10
reviewComments: Tifa's combat made me a Tifa main. The combos are so satisfying to pull off.
Barrett went from comic relief to genuinely compelling character. Great development.
Aerith's characterization is perfect. You can tell they knew what they were doing.
The music arrangements are godlike. One-Winged Angel remake? Chills. Literal chills.
Linearity is very FF13 at times but the corridor is so pretty I don't mind

review: As someone who's never played the original, this game SLAPS. The story is engaging, the characters are lovable, and the combat keeps you thinking. I don't understand why some veterans are mad about story changes - it seems good to me? The world feels alive, the side quests are hit or miss, but the main path is excellent. Graphics are gorgeous, especially character models. The synergy between party members in combat is great. Wall Market sequence is hilarious. Solid JRPG experience. 8.5/10
reviewComments: As a newcomer, I'm confused about the story change discourse but the game is great so whatever
Wall Market is comedy gold. The whole sequence had me laughing out loud.
Some side quests are fetch quest hell but others are genuinely interesting
Character models are insane. Cloud's hair probably has more polygons than entire PS1 games.
Combat synergy is underrated. Switching characters mid-battle feels so good

review: This remake makes me nostalgic for a game I played 25 years ago while also feeling completely fresh. That's impressive. Seeing Midgar in HD is surreal. The attention to detail is insane - every corner of this city is crafted with love. The English voice acting is shockingly good (Square Enix has improved!). Combat is deep with materia combinations. Hard mode is actually challenging. My biggest issue: feels incomplete because it's only part 1. But I'll gladly wait for the rest. 9/10
reviewComments: Midgar in HD is everything I imagined as a kid. The pizza structure is MASSIVE.
The English voice acting is genuinely great. No complaints. Massive improvement from past SE games.
Materia combinations are so deep. Still discovering new synergies after multiple playthroughs.
Hard mode is legit hard. Forces you to master the combat system.
The incompleteness hurts but at least each part is a full game's worth of content

review: Square Enix proved they can remake their classics without butchering them. FF7R respects the source while adding meaningful improvements. The combat is revolutionary for the series - finally action-based but keeping strategy. The story additions are mostly good (that ending though...). The game looks incredible on PS5. Minigames are fun throwbacks. Roche is a ridiculous addition and I love him. This is how you remake a beloved game. Take notes, other developers. Now hurry up with Part 3! 9/10
reviewComments: That ending was WILD. Time travel? Multiverse? Nomura doing Nomura things? I need answers.
Roche is the most Final Fantasy character ever created. Absolutely ridiculous. Perfect.
PS5 version is so smooth. 60fps makes combat feel even better.
Other developers need to study this remake. This is how you respect your legacy.
Part 3 can't come soon enough. The wait is torture.

review: The OG tactical shooter is BACK. Delta Force returns with modern graphics, refined gameplay, and that classic tactical feel. The operators are authentic, the weapons are varied, and the maps are well-designed for both PvP and PvE. The extraction mode is clearly influenced by Tarkov but it has its own flavor. Gunplay is satisfying with great audio design. Optimization is surprisingly good for a new release. If you miss classic tactical shooters or want something grounded, this delivers. 8.5/10
reviewComments: Classic tactical shooters are back! This feels like a spiritual successor to the originals.
Operators feel authentic. The attention to tactical detail is appreciated.
Extraction mode is good! Not just a Tarkov clone, has its own identity.
Audio design is phenomenal. Gunshots have weight and directionality.
Optimization being good at launch? In THIS economy? Shocking and welcome.

review: Delta Force making a comeback was unexpected but VERY welcome. The game balances arcade and simulation well - accessible but with depth. The class system adds variety to team composition. The vehicle gameplay is better than expected. Maps are large enough for strategic play but not so big you're walking forever. The progression system feels fair without being grindy. Cosmetics are reasonably priced. This is a solid tactical shooter in an era where we needed one. 8/10
reviewComments: The balance between arcade and sim is perfect. Not too casual, not too hardcore.
Class system forces teamwork. Playing with randoms can be rough but with a squad it's great.
Vehicle gameplay surprised me. Not just tacked on, actually fun and useful.
Progression feels fair. Not forcing you to grind for 100 hours to compete.
Cosmetics not being predatory? Crazy concept but I appreciate it

review: This game scratches the tactical military FPS itch that's been ignored for years. It's not trying to be Call of Duty, it's not trying to be Battlefield - it's doing its own thing. Slower, more methodical gameplay. Communication actually matters. The weapon customization is deep. The night vision gameplay is tense. The game modes are varied enough to keep things interesting. Not revolutionary but it's GOOD, and sometimes that's all you need. 8/10
reviewComments: Methodical gameplay is refreshing. Not every FPS needs to be a dopamine speedrun.
Communication mattering is rare nowadays. This actually rewards teamwork.
Weapon customization goes deep. Attachments actually affect handling meaningfully.
Night vision sections are tense. Limited visibility adds so much to the experience.
Good is underrated. Not every game needs to revolutionize the genre.

review: As an old-school Delta Force player, this modernization is respectful. It keeps the tactical roots while updating everything else. The movement feels weighty and realistic. No bunny hopping or sliding nonsense. Just good, grounded tactical gameplay. The AI in PvE is actually competent - they flank, suppress, communicate. PvP is competitive and skill-based. Maps have good flow. This is what modern military shooters should aspire to be. 8.5/10
reviewComments: The movement being weighty is so important. No crazy momentum physics, just tactical movement.
AI being good is rare! They actually use tactics instead of just rushing mindlessly.
PvP skill ceiling is high. Rewards good aim and tactics over twitch reflexes alone.
Map flow is great. Multiple approaches to every objective.
This is THE standard for modern military shooters. Finally someone got it right.

review: Delta Force said 'we're bringing back tactical shooters' and delivered. The game has soul - it's not a soulless live service cash grab. The developers clearly care. Updates are frequent and meaningful. The community is surprisingly non-toxic for an FPS. The extraction mode is addictive - risk vs reward is well balanced. Standard multiplayer is solid too. Graphics are clean and functional without being distracting. This is a game that knows what it wants to be and executes well. 8/10
reviewComments: Having soul in a modern FPS? Revolutionary concept. But this game has it.
Devs being responsive to feedback is so refreshing. They actually listen.
Non-toxic FPS community is like finding a unicorn. Treasure it while it lasts.
Extraction mode is so good. Every raid feels meaningful.
Clean graphics > over-designed chaos. Function over form done right.

review: The most ambitious tech demo ever created. Star Citizen is simultaneously incredible and frustrating. When it works, it's magical - seamless space to ground transitions, ship interiors you can walk around in, massive scale battles. When it doesn't work... well, you might fall through your ship and die. It's been in development for over a decade and still in alpha. But there's nothing else like it. If you want a space sim with unparalleled ambition and don't mind bugs, pledge. If you want a finished game, check back in 2035. 7/10 (potential 10/10)
reviewComments: Fell through my ship 3 times today. Still had fun. That's the Star Citizen experience.
The seamless transitions are actually witchcraft. No loading screens? In THIS economy?
Been following since 2013. I'll die before this game is finished. Worth it.
Nothing else comes close to this level of ambition. For better or worse.
2035 release date is optimistic. I'm thinking 2045 minimum.

review: Star Citizen is either the biggest scam in gaming or the most ambitious project ever attempted. Jury's still out. But I've sunk hundreds of hours into the alpha and had genuine moments of awe. Flying through asteroid fields in my Constellation, watching planets rotate in real-time, engaging in massive space battles - it's unlike anything else. But bugs are constant, progress is slow, and Squadron 42 is always '2 years away'. If you pledge, go in with eyes wide open. 6.5/10 (7.5/10 when it works)
reviewComments: Scam or genius? I've decided it's both. Schrödinger's game development.
Moments of awe are real. Then you crash and lose everything. Perfectly balanced.
Squadron 42 has been 2 years away since 2014. Time is a flat circle.
Going in with eyes open is crucial. Don't pledge rent money, pledge fun money.
When it works the rating jumps to 9/10. Problem is 'when it works' is 50% of the time

review: I pledged $45 in 2014. That starter ship is now worth... still $45. But I've gotten hundreds of hours of alpha gameplay so honestly? Not mad. Star Citizen is a test of patience. Updates come slowly but they're usually impressive. The ship designs are incredible - so much detail. The flight model is complex but rewarding. The community is passionate (some might say cult-like). It's jank as hell but there's genuine magic in the chaos. Will it ever release? Maybe. Do I care at this point? Not really. 7/10
reviewComments: Starter ship gang represent. We're all in this together.
The ship designs are genuinely art. I've spent hours just walking around my Carrack.
Cult-like community is accurate. But we're a friendly cult. Mostly.
Jank is part of the experience. I've made peace with the bugs.
Will it release? Yes. When? [ERROR: DATE NOT FOUND]

review: Star Citizen is the most 'Chris Roberts' game ever made - beautiful, ambitious, bloated, and perpetually unfinished. As a space sim fan, I appreciate what they're attempting. No other game lets you walk around your ship in real-time while flying through space. The tech is impressive. But the scope creep is REAL. Features get added while core gameplay loops remain incomplete. It's fun to dip into occasionally but it's not a daily driver game yet. Maybe one day. 7/10
reviewComments: Chris Roberts energy is 'what if we added EVERYTHING'. I respect it but also, finish something please.
Walking around ships while flying is so cool. Showed my friend and their jaw dropped.
Scope creep should be studied in project management classes as a cautionary tale.
Dipping in occasionally is the play. Treating it like a main game leads to disappointment.
One day this will be finished and it will be glorious. One day. Maybe.

review: Look, I've spent more money on this than I care to admit. Multiple ships, years of waiting, countless bugs. And you know what? I don't regret it. Star Citizen represents something gaming needs - ambition unconstrained by corporate deadlines. Yes it's messy. Yes it's taking forever. But when I'm in my Freelancer, landing on a moon, and seeing the planet I just came from in the sky? That's magic. No other game does this. It's flawed but it's special. 7.5/10, would fall through spaceship again
reviewComments: The money I've spent... let's not talk about it. My wife doesn't know. She can never know.
Ambition unconstrained is exactly what this is. For better or worse.
That moment of landing and looking back at the planet is genuinely breathtaking every time.
Flawed but special is the perfect description. It's broken but I love it.
Falling through spaceships is a rite of passage at this point

review: Destiny 2 is digital crack. The gunplay is the best in the industry - Bungie knows how to make guns feel GOOD. The power fantasy is real when you're demolishing enemies with your build. Raids are phenomenal with friends. BUT, the new player experience is terrible, content vaulting was a mistake, and the seasonal model is exhausting. I've played for 1000+ hours and I'm tired but I can't stop. The game is simultaneously the best and worst MMO-lite FPS. 8/10, help me I'm addicted
reviewComments: The gunplay is unmatched. Other shooters feel wrong after playing Destiny.
Raids with friends are peak gaming. Some of my best gaming memories are raid nights.
New player experience is a disaster. I tried to get friends into it. They quit immediately.
Content vaulting still makes me angry. I paid for that content, where did it go?
1000+ hours is rookie numbers in this community. I'm at 2500+. Send help.

review: Bungie created the perfect gameplay loop: shoot aliens, get loot, get stronger, shoot bigger aliens. It's simple but it WORKS. The moment-to-moment gameplay is addictive. Every class feels unique and fun. The endgame content is challenging and rewarding. The story has gotten significantly better (finally). But the FOMO is real, the grind can be exhausting, and Bungie's monetization decisions are questionable. Despite all that, I keep coming back. It's a love-hate relationship. 8/10
reviewComments: The gameplay loop is scientifically designed to trigger dopamine. Bungie has cracked the code.
Every class being fun is rare. Most games have a meta, Destiny lets you play how you want.
The story being good now is wild. Remember Red War? We've come so far.
FOMO is weaponized in this game. Miss a season? Too bad, content gone forever.
Love-hate is accurate. I complain constantly but I'm logging in daily.

review: As a returning player after 2 years, I'm completely lost. The story makes no sense, half the content I paid for is gone, and the game expects me to know things I've never learned. BUT the shooting is still incredible, the activities are fun, and the community is helpful. It's a shame Bungie makes it so hard to get back in. Once you're in though, the loop is addictive. If you're new, find a sherpa. You'll need one. 7.5/10
reviewComments: Being lost is the default state for returning players. The game explains nothing.
Content vaulting means I paid $40 for stuff that's literally gone. Still mad.
Community being helpful is the saving grace. Sherpas are saints.
The shooting being incredible is the only reason this game survives its own bad decisions.
New player experience is so bad it's funny. You just get thrown in with zero context.

review: Destiny 2 is a game I want to love but Bungie makes it so hard. The core gameplay is phenomenal - raids, dungeons, strikes all feel great. The gunplay is unmatched. The fashion game is strong. But the monetization is aggressive, the seasonal content is repetitive, and FOMO is baked into the design. I've been playing since D1 and I'm exhausted. Still, when a new raid drops? I'm there day one. It's Stockholm Syndrome but in video game form. 7.5/10
reviewComments: Core gameplay carrying this game is the theme. Remove that and it crumbles.
Fashion game is endgame. I've spent more time making my guardian look good than actual gameplay.
Monetization is wild. $100+ per year to experience everything? Yikes.
D1 veteran exhaustion is real. We're tired, Bungie.
Stockholm Syndrome is accurate. They hurt us but we keep coming back.

review: Destiny 2 does three things perfectly: shooting aliens, collecting loot, and making me angry at Bungie's decisions. The buildcrafting is deep when you understand it. The endgame is challenging. The community events are fun. But good luck figuring out what's going on as a new player. The story is scattered, the UI is confusing, and the tutorials are non-existent. Still, when you nail a build and feel like a god? No game does it better. 8/10, please fix new player experience Bungie
reviewComments: Buildcrafting is genuinely deep. 100 different ways to be OP.
Endgame content is why people stay. The raids are genuinely well designed.
Community events bring people together. Watching thousands of guardians complete a goal is cool.
New player experience has been complained about for YEARS. Bungie please.
God complex from a good build is unmatched. I AM THE MAIN CHARACTER.

review: AC finally goes to Japan and it was worth the wait. Playing as both a samurai and a shinobi offers great variety - Yasuke brings the action, Naoe brings the stealth. Feudal Japan is beautifully realized with incredible attention to detail. The combat is weighty and satisfying. Parkour through Japanese architecture is smooth. The dual protagonist system works well. Ubisoft clearly studied the setting extensively. If you've been waiting for AC in Japan, this delivers. Just prepare for typical Ubisoft map bloat. 8.5/10
reviewComments: Playing as Yasuke feels powerful. The combat when you switch to him is so satisfying.
Naoe's stealth sections are classic AC. This is what the series does best.
Feudal Japan is gorgeous. Cherry blossoms, shrines, castles - all beautifully done.
Ubisoft map bloat is still present. 400 collectibles on the map. Why.
Been waiting for AC Japan since AC1. Finally getting it feels surreal.

review: Assassin's Creed Shadows is what happens when Ubisoft actually listens to fans. We wanted Japan, we got Japan. The dual protagonist system means you can switch between playstyles - hack and slash or pure stealth. The story explores both samurai and ninja perspectives on the same events, which is clever. The world is dense with activities (maybe too dense). The historical accuracy seems solid. Combat is brutal and visceral. This feels like a return to form for the series. 8/10
reviewComments: Ubisoft listening to fans? Rare. But they delivered here.
Dual protagonist perspective on same events is narratively interesting. Good storytelling choice.
The world being too dense is classic Ubisoft. I have 100 hours of content and I'm overwhelmed.
Historical accuracy seems good but I'm not an expert. Looks authentic to me.
Return to form is what we needed. This feels like classic AC with modern improvements.

review: AC Shadows is gorgeous, fun, and massive. The setting is a dream come true - exploring feudal Japan as an assassin is everything I imagined. Yasuke's story is compelling and historically fascinating. Naoe is a great stealth protagonist. The missions have variety. The side content is abundant (too abundant). The main criticism: it's still a Ubisoft open world game with all the usual issues - busy work, repetitive activities, towers to climb. But the core experience is solid. 8/10
reviewComments: Feudal Japan setting is chef's kiss. They nailed the atmosphere.
Yasuke's story is really interesting. Historical figure in an AC game works well.
Naoe being a strong stealth character saves this from being just an action game.
Ubisoft formula is still Ubisoft formula. If you hate their style, this won't change your mind.
Core experience being solid is what matters. The bloat is optional.

review: This is the AC game I've wanted since 2007. Japan is perfect for parkour and stealth. The architecture, the rooftops, the forests - all designed for assassin gameplay. Switching between Yasuke and Naoe keeps gameplay fresh. The skill trees are deep. The equipment variety is great. The story balances historical events with AC lore well. My only gripe is performance could be better and some missions feel formulaic. But overall, this is a strong entry. 8.5/10
reviewComments: 2007 wait was long but worth it. This is what we asked for.
Japanese architecture is perfect for parkour. So many vertical options.
Skill trees being deep means lots of build variety. I like choices.
Performance issues are present but not game-breaking. Hopefully patches fix it.
Formulaic missions are classic AC. If you've played one, you know what to expect.

review: Assassin's Creed Shadows is fan service done right. The Japan setting is executed well, the protagonists are interesting, and the gameplay is refined. It's not revolutionary - it's still AC - but it's polished. The world is beautiful, the combat is satisfying, the stealth is solid. If you like AC games, you'll like this. If you're tired of the formula, this won't change your mind. But for fans waiting for AC Japan, this is a love letter. 8/10, worth the decades-long wait
reviewComments: Fan service done right is rare. This nails it without being pandering.
Not revolutionary but polished is fine. Sometimes you just want more of what works.
If you hate AC formula, skip this. It's refined, not reinvented.
Love letter to fans is accurate. They clearly made this for people who wanted Japan.
Decades-long wait is over. We can finally stop asking for AC Japan in every survey.

review: Marvel Rivals is Overwatch with superheroes and honestly? It works. The character roster is great - playing as Doctor Strange or Spider-Man feels authentic. The abilities are flashy and fun. Team composition matters. The 6v6 format is refreshing after OW went to 5v5. The maps are well designed with good flow. Netcode is solid. It's free-to-play without being predatory (so far). Not groundbreaking but it's FUN, which is what matters. If you like hero shooters, this is worth trying. 8/10
reviewComments: Finally a F2P game that's not aggressively predatory. Refreshing.
Playing as Doctor Strange and actually feeling like Doctor Strange? Rare W for adaptations.
6v6 being back is huge. Overwatch going 5v5 was a mistake and this proves it.
Team composition mattering is good design. Rewards teamwork over solo carry attempts.
Not groundbreaking but fun is sometimes all you need. Pure enjoyable chaos.

review: NetEase made a hero shooter that doesn't suck. Shocked. Marvel Rivals takes the Overwatch formula and adds Marvel flavor successfully. The synergies between heroes are cool - Iron Man + Hulk combos are sick. The monetization seems fair. The gameplay is fast and chaotic in the best way. Some heroes feel overtuned but that's expected at launch. The biggest praise: it's actually balanced for fun, not just competitive play. Casual matches are enjoyable. 8/10
reviewComments: NetEase finally made something good. Character development arc complete.
Hero synergies add depth. Combos are fun to discover and execute.
Monetization being fair is shocking for a F2P game. Color me surprised.
Some heroes are definitely OP but balance patches will come. Nature of live service.
Balanced for fun > balanced for esports. More games should do this.

review: As a lapsed Overwatch player, Marvel Rivals is exactly what I needed. The hero shooter genre was getting stale, this brings fresh energy. The Marvel IP is used well - characters have personality and their kits match their powers. The game modes are familiar but refined. Queue times are short. The community is still in the honeymoon phase (enjoy it while it lasts). Performance is great. This is a serious contender in the hero shooter space. 8.5/10
reviewComments: Lapsed OW players unite! We have a new home and it's surprisingly good.
Marvel IP being used well is rare. Usually licenses are wasted but this works.
Honeymoon phase won't last but I'm enjoying the positivity while it's here.
Queue times being short means the game is healthy. Good sign for longevity.
Serious contender is accurate. This could actually challenge the big names.

review: Marvel Rivals is surprisingly polished for a new hero shooter. Character designs are faithful, abilities feel impactful, and the gameplay loop is addictive. Playing as your favorite heroes never gets old. The ranked system is competitive without being toxic (yet). Casual modes are fun. The cosmetics are cool and reasonably priced. My main concern is long-term content updates - will NetEase support this or abandon it? But for now, it's great. 8/10
reviewComments: Polished at launch is rare nowadays. They did their homework.
Playing favorite heroes is the dream. Little me would be freaking out.
Ranked being competitive without toxicity won't last but I appreciate it now.
Cosmetics being reasonably priced? In THIS economy? Unheard of.
NetEase support is the big question mark. Track record is... mixed.

review: This game has no right to be this good. A F2P Marvel hero shooter from NetEase? Should be a disaster. Instead it's polished, balanced, and genuinely fun. The character roster at launch is solid with good variety. The maps encourage different playstyles. The abilities are creative and visually impressive. It respects your time - matches are quick, progression is fair. If they keep updating with new heroes and maps, this could be huge. 8.5/10, pleasantly surprised
reviewComments: Should be a disaster but it's great. 2025 is weird.
Launch roster being good means they understand pacing. Not overwhelming but substantial.
Respecting player time is so rare in F2P games. Massive W.
If they keep updating this could be massive. Big IF but I'm hopeful.
Pleasantly surprised is the theme of this game. Expectations were low, reality is high.

review: What a weird, janky, sometimes frustrating experience. Hello Neighbor has a cool premise - sneak into your neighbor's house and uncover secrets. The AI neighbor adapts to your tactics which is clever. The art style is unique and creepy. But the execution is rough. Controls are clunky, puzzles are obtuse, and the story is told through environmental storytelling that's too vague. It's interesting but flawed. Kids seem to love it though. The modding community is active. 6/10, interesting mess
reviewComments: The AI neighbor is cool in concept. In practice it's inconsistent but when it works, it's great.
Art style is creepy in the right way. Uncanny valley but intentional.
Puzzles being obtuse is frustrating. I looked up walkthroughs. No shame.
Kids loving this makes sense. It's like a playable creepypasta.
Interesting mess describes it perfectly. Ambitious but rough execution.

review: Hello Neighbor is a game of unrealized potential. The concept of an AI that learns and adapts is brilliant. The stealth gameplay can be tense. The mysterious narrative is intriguing. But the physics are wonky, the controls fight you, and progression can be confusing. It feels like an early access game that shipped too early. The YouTube/Twitch community made this bigger than it probably deserved but there's charm here. 6.5/10
reviewComments: Unrealized potential hurts. This could have been great with more dev time.
YouTube community definitely boosted this game. Content creators made it look better than it plays.
Physics being wonky leads to unintended comedy at least. Silver lining.
Shipped too early is the vibe. Needed another year in the oven.
Charm is present despite the flaws. That counts for something.

review: Playing this is like wrestling with game design itself. Every system fights against you - the controls, the physics, the puzzles. But there's something compelling about uncovering the mystery. The neighbor's house is like a puzzle box that actively tries to stop you. The dynamic AI is impressive when it works. It's janky and frustrating but also unique. Not for everyone but it has personality. The franchise spawned multiple games so clearly it resonated with some people. 6/10
reviewComments: Wrestling with game design is accurate. Every action feels like a struggle.
The mystery is compelling enough to push through the jank. That's impressive.
Dynamic AI when it works is genuinely cool. Problem is 'when it works'.
Multiple games in the franchise means someone likes it. Just not always me.
Personality > polish sometimes. This has personality at least.

review: Hello Neighbor is a great idea executed in a very okay way. Sneaking around, avoiding the AI neighbor, solving environmental puzzles - all good concepts. The problem is the game never explains itself well. Trial and error is fine but this takes it too far. The later acts get increasingly surreal and confusing. Kids enjoy the mystery and the creepy vibes. Adults might find it tedious. It's not bad, just rough around the edges. 6.5/10
reviewComments: Great idea, okay execution is a tragedy in game development. Tale as old as time.
Not explaining itself is either genius or lazy. Probably lazy but I'll give benefit of doubt.
Later acts being surreal is interesting narratively but confusing mechanically.
Kids vs adults enjoyment gap is real. This is definitely aimed at younger players.
Rough around edges is generous. More like rough in the middle too.

review: This game is a fever dream with inconsistent quality. Sometimes it's fun and tense, sometimes it's frustrating and obtuse. The neighbor's AI can be brilliant or broken depending on the day. The house design is creative with hidden passages and secrets everywhere. The story is vague to the point of incomprehensibility. But it has a unique vibe that's memorable.
